<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 170, 291]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 904, 291]]<|/det|> **9702/52** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 904, 312]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation **May/June 2012** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 322, 904, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour 15 minutes** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 353]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 368, 372]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 396, 386, 407]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 422, 718, 434]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 437, 325, 448]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 607, 463]]<|/det|> You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 465, 598, 476]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 479, 384, 490]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 505, 256, 516]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 519, 764, 531]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 603, 556]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 757, 571]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 723, 904, 848]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 873, 106]]<|/det|>
A hot air balloon is tied to the ground using a rope. As the wind blows with speed \(v\), the rope makes an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal, as shown in Fig 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 120, 816, 505]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 526, 506, 543]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 558, 568, 575]]<|/det|>
<pre>It is suggested that \(\tan \theta\) is inversely proportional to \(v^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 590, 873, 653]]<|/det|>
<pre>To model the hot air balloon in the laboratory, a balloon filled with helium is used. Design a laboratory experiment using a small helium-filled balloon to test the relationship between \(\theta\) and \(v\). You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 667, 146, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 667, 397, 683]]<|/det|>
the procedure to be followed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 698, 146, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 698, 415, 714]]<|/det|>
the measurements to be taken,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 729, 146, 747]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 728, 351, 744]]<|/det|>
the control of variables,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 760, 148, 777]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 759, 355, 775]]<|/det|>
the analysis of the data,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 790, 146, 808]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 790, 441, 806]]<|/det|>
the safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 806, 875, 823]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 850, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates how the resonant length \(L\) of a loaded wire varies with frequency \(f\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 106, 705, 460]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 483, 509, 500]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 515, 625, 532]]<|/det|>
For six different frequencies, the student records the length \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[302, 717, 650, 733]]<|/det|>
<pre>Question 2 continues on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 564, 90]]<|/det|> 
It is suggested that \(f\) and \(L\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 97, 525, 129]]<|/det|>

\[f = \frac{1}{2L}\sqrt{\frac{T}{\mu}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 558, 151]]<|/det|>

where \(T\) is the tension in the wire and \(\mu\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 166, 146, 184]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 873, 198]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(f\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(1 / L\) on the \(x\)-axis. Determine an expression for the gradient in terms of \(T\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 305, 873, 322]]<|/det|>

gradient = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 336, 148, 354]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 336, 467, 353]]<|/det|>
Values of \(f\) and \(L\) are given in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 370, 753, 562]]<|/det|>

\(f/Hz\)\(L/10^{-2}m\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 730, 180, 747]]<|/det|>

An expression for \(\mu\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 475, 516, 494]]<|/det|>
\[\mu = \rho \pi r^2\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 777, 524]]<|/det|>
where the density \(\rho\) of the wire is \(8800 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\) and \(r\) is the radius of the wire.
